persona.name: Derek Malone

occupation.title: Journeyman Carpenter / Site Foreman
occupation.organization: Midwest General Contractors (mid-sized regional construction company)
occupation.description: Derek is a journeyman carpenter who commonly acts as site foreman on residential renovation and small commercial jobs. Responsibilities include: reading and interpreting blueprints for remodels, framing and finishing carpentry, on-site crew supervision (3-8 people), coordinating subcontractors (electricians, plumbers), ordering and tracking materials, enforcing safety protocols (OSHA basics), clocking and documenting daily labor hours, basic client communication and change-order explanations, occasionally operating skid-steer and forklift. He estimates labor and simple costs for small jobs, mentors apprentices, and steps in for hands-on work on tight schedules. He excels at problem-solving on-site, improvising practical fixes when plans conflict with field conditions, and keeping the job moving when deadlines are tight. He is paid hourly with overtime and occasional premium on-call pay; household income falls in the $50k–$99k band when combined with his wife's part-time income.

persona.residence: West Columbus suburb, Ohio (medium-density suburban neighborhood, 20 minutes to downtown)
persona.education: High school graduate (Central High School, Columbus). Completed vocational evening courses in carpentry and construction safety. Holds OSHA-10 certification, NCCER basic carpentry modules completed, forklift and skid-steer operator certificates. No college degree; informal on-the-job apprenticeships and trade schooling.
long_term_goals: Stay employed in construction and move into a stable foreman or small-business-owner role within the next 5 years so he can control schedules and income.
Buy and renovate a modest lakeside or small cabin property in northern Ohio for weekend getaways and to host friends for board game weekends.
Fully fund retirement to avoid relying on Social Security; increase retirement contributions and build an emergency fund equivalent to six months' expenses.
Improve physical health (lose 15-20 pounds, strengthen back and knees) to keep working in construction into his 60s.
Develop a respected local board-game night with rotating hosts and bring more people from the neighborhood into hobby gaming, making it accessible to newcomers.
Support his wife Emily in her career goals and maintain a marriage that is partnership-first (mutual respect, shared finances, shared chores).
Build and maintain a reliable crew of 3–4 skilled tradespeople so he can take on small contracting jobs on weekends for extra income.
Learn more about basic home finance and taxes so he can make smarter decisions as a homeowner and hobbyist investor.
Be a steady presence in his parents' and sister's lives — help with small repairs, keep family traditions alive (holiday dinners, fishing trips).
Retire with enough travel budget to see a few national parks and board-game conventions in his 60s with his wife.
persona.style: Colloquial Midwestern. Speaks with a mild Columbus/Ohio inflection: dropped t's sometimes, friendly and direct. Uses plain language, construction jargon ("run the header," "rip that board," "square up"), and occasional profanity when excited or frustrated, but avoids targeted insults — mostly self-deprecating sarcasm. Typically casual and approachable in manner: a firm handshake, steady eye contact, and a slow-to-medium-paced voice. Laughs loudly, tells work stories, and punctuates explanations with small gestures (thumbs-up, pointing at imaginary studs). He uses short text messages with emojis to his wife and friends, prefers phone calls for quick coordination at job sites, and often speaks in metaphors drawn from tools or machines. Mannerisms: scratches his jaw or rubs the back of his neck when thinking, taps a work boot rhythmically when seated, and unconsciously runs a thumb along his wedding band while listening. Politeness and conflict avoidance are noticeable: he smooths over disagreements with jokes, agrees to compromise, and defers to elders or clients when tension rises. In formal settings (permitting permits, city office, subcontractor meetings) he cleans up language, speaks respectfully, and brings a notebook with measurements and notes.

traits: High sensation-seeking: enjoys new projects, hands-on tasks, and the thrill of tackling unexpected on-site challenges.
Impulsive in purchases and hobbies: buys a board-game kickstarter or a used tool on a whim when excited.
Agreeable and cooperative: tends to trust coworkers, helps neighbors, and mediates disputes to keep peace.
Practical and action-oriented: prefers doing over theorizing; wants immediate, tangible progress.
Risk-tolerant on occasion: comfortable with moderate physical risk at work, more cautious financially but gives into impulse buying.
Loyal to friends and family: long-term friendships and steady marriage despite occasional friction.
Good-humored and storytelling: remembers funny episodes from jobs and shares them to keep morale high.
Modestly goal-directed: has plans but can be flexible about the path; likes achievable milestones.
Occasionally short-tempered under stress, but quick to apologize and repair relationships.
Community-minded: volunteers at the neighborhood volunteer firewood program and helps with local Habitat for Humanity builds.

openness.description: Moderate. Curious about new games, trade techniques, and small travel; not into academic abstraction. Enjoys novelty that has a practical payoff.

conscientiousness.description: Somewhat high. Reliable on the job, shows up early, keeps tools organized, but is less meticulous with long-term paperwork and personal finances.

extraversion.description: High. Energized by group settings: crew, barbecues, and game nights. Comfortable in social situations, enjoys banter and being in the center of a small group.

agreeableness.description: High. Cooperative, trusting, and conflict-avoidant. Often the peacemaker in his friend group and at work.

neuroticism.description: Moderate-low. Generally even-tempered but experiences stress in financial uncertainty, loud arguments, or when his competence is questioned.

general_likes: Prefers medium to heavy strategy games that reward clever problem solving and social interaction.
Enjoys games that blend tactical choices with player interaction (trading, negotiation, alliances).
Likes games that finish in 90–180 minutes — long enough for depth but not marathon sessions.
Appreciates games with clear physical components (miniatures, wooden pieces, dice, boards) over purely abstract cards.
Values accessible rule explanations for new players, but loves a game with a deep strategy once learned.
Prefers face-to-face play and the social atmosphere of a dining table with 3–5 players.
Occasionally plays solo modes when he wants to learn rules before bringing a game to the group.
Likes games with strong themes (exploration, railroads, space, frontier towns) that create memorable stories.
Enjoys drafting mechanics, area control, resource management, and worker placement mechanics.
Often picks up a first-print or used copy at a local game store or trade groups before buying new releases.
Keeps an eye on Kickstarter for small-press hobby games but is selective about backing pricey projects.
Appreciates games that scale well with different player counts (2 to 5 players).
Enjoys a mix of competition and occasional cooperative play with his wife and friends.
Values replayability and asymmetric player roles that create varied sessions.
Likes games that encourage trash-talk in a good-natured way and foster social banter between rounds.
Prefers rulebooks with examples and quick reference sheets for in-play clarity.
Often buys expansions for his top ten games, but only the expansions that add meaningful strategic depth.
Cares about durability of components — upgrades from cardboard tokens to wooden bits are appreciated.
Likes when games have a 'moment of tension' near the end — a comeback potential.
Favors games that produce memorable one-liners and in-session stories to reminisce about later.
favorite_games_and_details: Ticket to Ride — like as an accessible gateway for new players and occasional family play; prefers Europe map for variety.
Catan (base & Cities & Knights) — appreciates early-game trading and the social table talk it generates, has a custom wooden board variant that he built.
Terraforming Mars — favorite heavy solo/coop option; enjoys engine-building and draft phases; owns the Hellas & Elysium map expansions.
Scythe — likes the engine-building and alternate-history theme; enjoys the miniatures; keeps the game for special sessions.
Wingspan — enjoys the art and theme as a lighter, relaxing alternative; often uses it as a palate cleanser between heavy games.
Root — loves asymmetric factions and player stories that emerge; prefers playing as Marquise or Eyrie for different feels.
Risk (classic) — nostalgic; brings it out when friends want a long, boisterous evening of conflict.
Pandemic — cooperative fix for when the group wants to work together, plays with wife as best cooperator.
Twilight Imperium (occasionally) — has played a 6–8 hour session once; respects it for epic scale, but rarely schedules it.
Eclipse — space exploration and fleet management appeals on strategy nights.
Azul — enjoys the lighter puzzle and pattern-building on casual nights; appreciates the tactile tiles.
Root: The Riverfolk Expansion — likes adding unique factions to rotate the table experience.
Carcassonne — classic tile-laying for quick filler games; enjoys the simplicity and luck-management balance.
7 Wonders — likes drafting and simultaneous play; good for 3–7 player groups that prefer fast rounds.
Brass: Birmingham — enjoys economic engine-building when the group is in a heavy mood; appreciates the historical industry theme.
Gloomhaven (box) — owns Gloomhaven-inspired lighter campaigns like 'Gloomhaven: Jaws of the Lion' for approachable campaigns.
Small World — likes the mix of fantasy whims and area control in a less intense setting than Risk.
Clank! — hybrid deck-building and board exploration; enjoys the push-your-luck tension with friends.
Agricola (family version) — likes the resource management and feeding mechanics; used to play with his uncle.
Root digital/app versions — uses apps to learn rules and practice solo before group sessions.
favorite_expansions_and_components: Extra card sleeves for favorite deck-building games.
Upgraded wooden pieces for Catan and Terraforming Mars (resource cubes and metal coins).
Custom storage inserts for faster setup/teardown.
House-made score pads and laminated player aids.
A favorite tablecloth that prevents components from sliding.
LED lamp for night games to reduce glare.
Snack trays and coasters to keep grease away from components.
A mechanic collection of special dice for different game moods.
A rolling cart he built to transport games and drinks to friend's houses.
Printed player reference sheets that he shares with new players.
how_he_plays: Friendly but competitive: jokes, teases, but dislikes personal attacks.
Will bend rules sometimes for smoother play with newbies, but insists on official rules for tournaments.
Teaches with patience — uses a two-turn demo to get players into a game quickly.
Enjoys narrating in-game events ("That was a brutal road connection!") to keep energy high.
Will trade aggressively in Catan but apologizes later if someone is genuinely harmed by the trade.
Prefers in-person meetups on Friday nights at his house or rotating to a friend's basement.
Schedules intentional 'new-game nights' where they try a different title each month.
Keeps a spreadsheet of who owns which games in the group to avoid duplicate purchases.
where_and_when: Friday night game nights at his house (7–11 PM) with 4–6 friends.
Occasional Saturday afternoon sessions for longer games (2–6 PM).
Plays at a local game store once a month for demo nights and to meet new players.
Brings a couple of filler games to family gatherings for cousins and in-laws.
Hosts a holiday gaming marathon (Friendsgiving) with potluck snacks.
Uses the digital versions to learn solo when traveling or on job downtime.
snacks_drinks_for_game_nights: Rotating craft beer selection (pilsner, APA, amber) — prefers local Ohio craft breweries (e.g., Columbus Brewing Co., North High Brewing).
Pizza: half-pepperoni, half-veggie for the group; orders from a reliable neighborhood pizzeria.
Pretzel bites with mustard and cheese dip.
Sliced meats and cheeses on a board for grazing.
Chips and salsa, but uses bowls to keep grease off components.
Root beer and cola for non-drinkers, plus a bottled water for each player.
Homemade brownies baked by his wife Emily for dessert.
Pre-cut veggie platter for balance and to pace the alcohol consumption.

likes: Comfort foods: grilled burgers, mashed potatoes, meatloaf, fried chicken.
Regional favorites: Cincinnati chili occasionally, Ohio-style barbecue.
Breakfast: bacon, eggs, and thick-cut toast or an egg-and-cheese biscuit on work mornings.
Coffee: prefers dark roast, drinks black in the morning but will take coffee with cream on weekends.
Beer: favors local craft pale ales, amber ales and occasional stouts on colder days.
Occasional whiskey (bourbon) neat for special occasions.
Grilling: loves to grill on weekends and experiments with rubs for ribs and brisket.
Comfort desserts: apple pie and ice cream.
Simple salads when his wife pushes for lighter meals; likes a chunky Cobb or Caesar variation.
dislikes: Overly spicy or exotically flavored foods that mask the primary ingredient.
Tiny 'gourmet' portions that look like a sample rather than a meal.
Expensive wine lists he can't pronounce — prefers straightforward labels.

music: Classic rock (Springsteen, Tom Petty), some alt-country (Jason Isbell), a soft spot for 90s alternative (Pearl Jam).
Likes playlists for work: driving rock, upbeat rhythms to stay motivated on-site.
Enjoys live local bands and small tavern gigs.
tv_and_movies: Enjoys action movies, gritty dramas, and documentaries about building or historical subjects.
Likes sports coverage: college football (Ohio State fan), occasional NFL.
Regularly watches how-to YouTube channels on woodworking and tool maintenance.
reading_and_online: Reads board-game rulebooks, Reddit threads (r/boardgames), and a couple of local news feeds.
Follows a few construction trade blogs and YouTube channels for technique updates.

transport_and_tech.car: Drive a well-maintained 2016 Ford F-150 used for jobsite hauling, with an aftermarket tool box and roof rack for ladders.
transport_and_tech.phone: Mid-priced smartphone used for group chats, photos of job progress, and rules PDFs for games.
transport_and_tech.tech_use: Comfortable with spreadsheets, navigation apps, and construction estimating apps; not an early adopter but buys tech that solves a problem.

nuances: Values small-government ideas when it comes to taxes and regulation of small businesses but supports reasonable safety regulations on construction sites.
Patriotic and proud of local manufacturing; supports policies that help blue-collar jobs.
Strongly supports closing the gun-show loophole and background checks—believes in responsible gun ownership with reasonable checks.
Skeptical of extreme partisan politics; prefers pragmatic problem-solving at the local level.
Votes in local and national elections and follows local candidates who emphasize infrastructure, jobs, and public safety.

beliefs: Hard work and showing up matters — you earn respect by being dependable on the job.
People should take responsibility for their own lives, but community safety nets are important for catastrophic failure.
Guns should be owned responsibly; background checks reduce impulsive violence and should be expanded to close loopholes like gun-show sales.
Supporters of the Second Amendment can also support reasonable regulation — the two are not mutually exclusive.
Local manufacturing and trades deserve public support because they provide steady middle-class livelihoods.
Unions can be useful when they protect workers' safety and fair wages, though he has mixed feelings about high union dues.
Taxes should be reasonable; he dislikes wasteful spending but tolerates taxes that fund roads, schools, and police.
Healthcare access for major emergencies is important; he favors pragmatic solutions that don't bankrupt families.
School vocational programs are undervalued — high schools should offer more trade apprenticeships.
Housing affordability is a growing problem; zoning reform that allows sensible infill is worth considering.
Immigration policies should be practical: border control matters, but legal pathways for work are necessary for many industries.
Environmental stewardship matters locally — he recycles, conserves energy at home, and supports sensible environmental protections that don't cripple local jobs.
Climate change is real and affects weather patterns that in turn impact construction schedules; adaptation is pragmatic.
Politeness and civility in discourse are underused; people should disagree respectfully.
Crime should be addressed with both law enforcement and community programs that offer alternatives for young people.
Local businesses should be supported; he prefers buying from neighborhood shops when quality and price are fair.
Debt is dangerous — he avoids carrying large, unsecured consumer debt and encourages building savings.
Owning a home is a worthwhile goal but should not become a source of crushing stress.
Technology is useful for efficiency but over-reliance on screens harms social bonds.
Mental health should be destigmatized — people should seek help; he personally would see a counselor if stress became unmanageable.
Public schools need better vocational options but also basic academic rigor.
People should be honest about skills — don't promise you can do something you can't; learn and practice instead.
Rules and permits exist for a reason — shortcuts on permits in construction can lead to long-term liability.
Good neighbors and small acts of help (lending a drill, mowing a lawn) maintain neighborhoods more than policing alone.
He trusts local officials more than distant ones; county and city leaders have more impact on day-to-day life.
Sports and shared rituals (tailgating, reunions) create bonds that help communities weather hard times.
Spending on experiences (a vacation, a memorable board-game convention) is often more valuable than buying more stuff.
He believes in second chances for people who want to change but expects accountability.
Religion is a private matter; faith is respected but should not be forced into public governance.
He is skeptical of quick-fix political promises; prefers plans with clear funding and implementation details.
Voting is a civic duty — even if nobody he likes is on the ballot.
He supports equal opportunity but recognizes systemic issues that create unequal starting lines; community-level solutions are practical starting points.
Consumer protection matters: businesses should be honest about warranties and work quality.
He believes in mentoring younger crew members — passing on trade knowledge is honorable.
People should enjoy their hobbies and friendships — hobbies like board games are legitimate ways to form deep social bonds.
He supports targeted investment in public infrastructure because roads and utilities directly affect small business and construction work.
He is wary of concentrated corporate power that squeezes small contractors and homebuilders.
He believes gun safety training and secure storage are responsibilities of owners, not just regulations.
skills: Framing and finishing carpentry (doors, window framing, trim work, cabinet installation).
Blueprint reading and basic plan interpretation for residential remodels.
Crew leadership and scheduling: coordinates 3–8 person crews, sequences trades, and mitigates delays.
Basic estimating for labor and small materials, preparing change order explanations for clients.
Operating and maintaining small heavy equipment: skid-steer, forklift, portable saws, and compressors.
Tool maintenance: sharpens saw blades, tunes nail guns, and maintains hand tools.
Safety implementation: enforces PPE, fall protection setups, and basic OSHA-compliant practices.
Problem-solving on-site: quick measurement improvisation, creative solutions for mismatched studs or unexpected plumbing.
Basic plumbing and electrical repairs for renovation contexts (not licensed but able to coordinate pros and do minor fixes).
Client communication: explains technical constraints in plain language and manages expectations.
Teaching and mentoring apprentices: onboarding new helpers and providing practical instruction.
Basic woodworking: making custom shelves, minor cabinetry repairs, and building outdoor furniture.
Basic vehicle maintenance and trailer handling for hauling materials.
Time management: prioritizing tasks to hit rainy-day contingencies and client deadlines.
Event and household hosting: organizes game nights, potlucks, and small volunteer projects.

general: Arrives early to site, drinks black coffee, and checks the day's weather forecast.
Carries a small pocket notebook with a pencil for measurements and quick sketches.
Kills energy-draining conflicts by joking and proposing concrete compromises.
Buys new hobby items impulsively after watching unboxing videos or enthusiastic reviews.
Keeps tools meticulously organized; his truck toolbox is labeled and orderly.
Sends group texts on game-night logistics and polls friends for the next title.
Will volunteer to help neighbors with small house repairs without expecting payment.
Likes to show off a small 'win' at day's end — a finished trim run or a successful drywall patch.
Uses social media sparingly: posts photos of finished jobs or big game-night group shots.
Paces himself socially — energetic at gatherings but values at-home quiet Sunday mornings.

morning: Makes strong black coffee and eats a quick breakfast (two eggs, toast, bacon sometimes).
Checks weather and job messages, loads the truck, packs a thermos, and arrives on-site by 6:30 AM.
Gives a quick huddle to the crew, assigns tasks, identifies safety hazards for the day.
workday: Breaks: a 15-minute mid-morning coffee/snack and a 30–45 minute lunch, usually a sandwich or leftovers.
Rotates between hands-on work (framing, cutting, measuring) and administrative tasks (ordering, calls, logging time).
Occasionally leaves site mid-day to pick up materials from supplier or speak with a client.
Wraps and secures tools before leaving; leaves the site in a state that protects materials from weather overnight.
evening: Returns around 5:30–6:30 PM depending on overtime.
Shower and decompress with music or a quick TV show clip.
Dinner with his wife Emily; they discuss the day and any household tasks.
On game-night Fridays, clears the dining table, sets up the game, and hosts friends until 10–11 PM.
Spends 30–60 minutes tidying the house or prepping tools for the next day on non-game nights.
weekend: Saturday: works on a small side job or personal woodworking project in the garage in the morning.
Saturday afternoon: errands, grocery run, occasional hobby shopping for board games or used tools.
Sunday: relaxed morning, coffee and paper, church or community event sometimes, then a family dinner and short planning for the week.
Once a month lawn-and-gutter maintenance for his parents' house or a friend's property in exchange for a home-cooked meal.

physical.overall: Generally good for a 41-year-old blue-collar worker. Strong functional strength from manual labor but with hobby-related sedentary tendencies on off-days.
physical.weight: Slightly overweight (BMI in the overweight range), aiming to lose 15–20 pounds.
physical.cardiovascular: Occasional borderline high blood pressure readings; advised to monitor sodium and alcohol intake.
physical.injuries: Old left knee sprain from high school soccer, occasional lower back strain from lifting (managed with stretches and OTC pain relievers).
physical.fitness: Does manual labor all week providing baseline fitness; supplements with weekend woodworking and occasional jogging. Intends to add targeted back-strengthening exercises.
physical.sleep: Usually sleeps 6.5–7 hours, earlier on work nights. On game nights, stays up later and may feel groggy the next morning.
physical.substances: Occasional social alcohol (3–5 beers on a Friday night) and the occasional bourbon with friends. Non-smoker. Does not use recreational drugs.

mental.overall: Stable mood with low-to-moderate stress levels. Enjoys hobbies that relieve stress. Some anxiety around finances when unexpected expenses occur.
mental.mental_health_history: No diagnosed chronic mental illness. Would consider counseling if major stressors arise. Uses friends and wife as primary emotional supports.
mental.coping: Uses board games and hands-on projects to decompress. Keeps a problem-solving attitude rather than ruminating.

medical_history: Childhood: routine vaccinations and minor childhood illnesses.
Adolescent sports-related injuries (left knee sprain), fully recovered with periodic soreness.
No major surgeries. Minor mole removal once.
Periodic seasonal allergies (hay fever) treated with OTC antihistamines.
Routine physical care: sees PCP every 1–3 years, dental checkups twice a year.

relationships.name: Emily Malone
relationships.description: Married for 8 years. Emily works part-time as an administrative assistant at a local medical practice. They share household responsibilities and finances. Emily is the more cautious financial planner while Derek is more impulsive with hobby purchases; they balance each other. No children by choice for now; both enjoy having more time for hobbies and travel. Emily is often the calm voice who helps Derek reflect before a big purchase. They host regular game nights together and collaborate on menu planning for hosting.

relationships.name: Mike Alvarez
relationships.description: Works with Derek as a fellow carpenter. Longtime friend from apprenticeship. Reliable, enjoys trading tools and old job stories. Plays in Derek's core board-game group.

relationships.name: Tony Richards
relationships.description: Competitive player, brings snacks and beer. Teases Derek about impulse buys but is a steady presence at game nights.

relationships.name: Linda Malone
relationships.description: Lives 15 minutes away. Emotional anchor and good cook. Derek helps her with small repairs and takes her to medical appointments when needed.

relationships.name: Robert Malone
relationships.description: Retired machinist. Taught Derek how to use power tools and instilled a strong work ethic. Occasional fishing buddy in summer.
relationships.political_relation: Shares Republican-leaning views but more conservative on social issues.

relationships.name: Hannah Malone
relationships.description: Lives out of state but visits during holidays. They text frequently and reminisce about childhood.

relationships.name: Local board-game group
relationships.description: A rotating group of 6–10 players including friends from work, neighbors, and two couples they met at the local game store. They trust one another, loan games, and help organize a small annual weekend retreat.

relationships.name: Clients and subcontractors
relationships.description: A web of repeat clients who call Derek back for repairs, a few reliable subcontractors he prefers to hire, and a local permit office contact who knows his name.

other_facts: Born and raised in a working-class neighborhood outside Columbus; the son of a machinist father and a school cafeteria worker mother.
Became interested in carpentry as a teenager helping his dad build workbenches in the garage.
Was on the high school football team for two years until a knee injury pushed him toward woodworking and shop class.
Met his wife Emily at a local summer festival; she was volunteering at a charity booth and he was helping fix the stage platform.
They married in a modest backyard ceremony with family and some coworkers in attendance.
They deliberately do not have children yet; the couple enjoys freedom for travel, hobbies, and financial planning.
Derek once rebuilt a neighbor's porch after a storm in a weekend, which led to five referral jobs.
Has a scar on his left thumb from a table saw incident in his early twenties; now religious about blade guards and PPE.
Built much of the custom shelving in his home himself and enjoys showing friends the 'handmade' details.
Hosts an annual Friendsgiving game-and-food night where vintage games come out and everyone brings a dish.
Once worked overtime for three weeks to help a single mother finish a kitchen remodeling project pro bono as a community gesture.
Has a small collection of vintage tools inherited from his grandfather; keeps a favorite antique brace and bit on display.
Is a member of a local Facebook community group for neighborhood swaps and often posts 'free lumber' when remodeling leftovers are available.
Kept a journal of every major renovation job with photos and lesson notes for future estimates.
Took a week-long family road trip to the Great Smoky Mountains one year and still quotes moments from the trip; hopes to do more national park travel.
Volunteered at a Habitat for Humanity build in his twenties and now tries to help on one or two community projects a year.
Enjoys fixing up older houses rather than new construction because of the problem-solving involved when dealing with older materials and quirks.
Has a ritual of checking and rechecking measurements three times before cutting critical pieces.
Once won a small local carpentry competition for a handcrafted coffee table design.
Owns a small woodshop in his garage with a table saw, router table, band saw, and a dust collection system he built himself.
Built his own rolling game cart to take games and snacks to friend's houses; it's a point of pride.
Kept a small emergency fund for years; had to dip into it once for an unexpected transmission repair but replenished it over six months.
Attended one board-game convention (a regional BGG Con) and hopes to attend a larger convention when finances allow.
Has an annual tradition of taking his dad fishing the first weekend of May; they talk about family and work and laugh about old jobs.
Once impulsively bid on a rare board-game edition at an online auction and lost sleep watching the final minutes; learned to set limits after that.
Has a small tattoo of a vintage hammer on his right forearm commemorating his trade and his grandfather.
Speaks fondly of a retired foreman who took him under his wing early in his career and taught him how to lead without yelling.
Is proud of the fact that his crews rarely miss deadlines and their customers often provide repeat business and referrals.
Enjoys teaching neighborhood teens basic tool safety during summer afternoons as an informal mentorship activity.
Has a soft spot for old-route diners and will plan a detour to stop at a roadside joint for a burger and pie on a weekend drive.
Occasionally takes night classes at the local community college for specific trade updates (new code requirements, advanced framing techniques).
Owns a spreadsheet where he tracks game wins/losses among his core gaming group and uses it to pick teams or match players for balanced experiences.
His wife Emily once negotiated a better health insurance plan for the family through her part-time job, which improved their household finances.
Derek still keeps a cardboard box of childhood memorabilia: baseball cards, a high-school letterman patch, and a worn-out board game he loved as a kid.
Once helped organize a neighborhood storm clean-up after a sudden windstorm, coordinating volunteers and tools.
Keeps a laminated emergency contact list in his truck with numbers for family, key subcontractors, and his primary supplier.
Earned an informal reputation among local contractors as someone who 'gets uncomfortable problems solved on tight timelines.'
Has a habit of humming classic rock songs when working alone on repetitive tasks; the crew often sings along.
Saved up for years to buy a quality table for hosting games; it was a financial priority because he values shared social time.
Has an old flip phone voicemail saved from his father that he listens to occasionally for nostalgia and to remember his dad's voice and humor.
